Introducing Python
Basic Geospatial Manipulations

title: GEOG 441 - Lecture 1
text:
Why learn Python

It allows for more flexibility than a GUI based GIS program.
Other GIS applications (e.g. QGIS, ArcGIS, postGIS) often have a Python interface.
generally a widely used language.

title: GEOG 441 - Lecture 1
text:
Basic Python data types



Type
Example(s)




String
'Dude!'


Float
1.2


Int
3


Tuple
('x', 'y'), (1, 2), ('x', 3.2)


List
['x', 'y'], [1, 2], ['x', 3.2]


Dict
`{‘dogs’: 26, ‘cats’, 100}


etc…
there are others

title: GEOG 441 - Lecture 1
text:
Vector Data

Most often we interact with vector data using GeoPandas

GeoPandas is an extension of Pandas.
Uses Fiona, which in-turn relies on GDAL and OGR, to read and write.
Vector data is handled by the Shapely module, which relies on GEOS.
GEOS implements the OGC Simple Features geometry

Projections are managed by pyproj which is built upon PROJ

title: GEOG 441 - Lecture 1
text:
Shapely
Shapely Geometric Objects consist of coordinate tuples: + Point - (x, y) or three dimensional (x, y, z) + LineString + Polygon

title: GEOG 441 - Lecture 1
text:
A plot
Python


import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
